documentType: character reference letter / bail support letter
summary: A confidential letter submitted to Judge Alison J. Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail application in her criminal case. The author, whose name is redacted, attests to Maxwell's character, denies the allegations against her, explains her need to hide from the press and vigilantes, and offers to co-sign a bond and provide 24/7 custody if she is released.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom this confidential letter in support of bail is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the letter. The author defends her character, asserts her innocence, explains her reasons for staying hidden, and supports her release on bail.

persons.name: Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'the late Mr. Epstein'. The author contrasts Maxwell's willingness to undergo depositions with Epstein's decision to take the Fifth Amendment.

connections.description: Implied association as the author contrasts Maxwell's legal conduct (not taking the Fifth) with that of 'the late Mr. Epstein and others'.
The author claims a long-standing personal relationship, having known Maxwell since she was growing up, trusts her with children, and is willing to co-sign a bond and provide 24/7 custody.

events.title: UK Sun Newspaper Bounty Offer
events.description: The UK newspaper The Sun offered a £10,000 'bounty' for anyone who could get them in front of Ghislaine Maxwell, which the letter author describes as shocking, scary, and an incitement to violence.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell's Arrest
events.description: Referenced as the point up until which Maxwell had never been charged, arrested, or interviewed. Her arrest is the context for the bail hearing.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The author offers to co-sign a $1.5 million bond for Ghislaine Maxwell's bail and to provide 24/7 personal custody in a New York residence.
The letter asserts Ghislaine Maxwell never left the United States after Epstein's death, contrary to media rumors placing her in Brazil, London, Israel, or France.
The author claims Maxwell went into hiding due to fear of press, vigilantes, and death threats, citing a specific £10,000 bounty offered by The Sun newspaper in November 2019.
The author contrasts Maxwell's willingness to undergo depositions in civil litigation with Jeffrey Epstein's decision to invoke the Fifth Amendment.
The letter's author is redacted, but they claim a long personal history with Maxwell and express absolute confidence in her character and that she will not flee if released on bail.
